title: Firmware Engineer
description:
Industry:Â GamingRemote work:Â 100%Remuneration: (up to 142 PLN/h net + VAT or up to 32 EUR/h net+ vat depends on experience)Assignment type:Â B2BÂ Project length:Â Â Long-term cooperationProject language: EnglishDESCRIPTION:We are seeking aÂ Firmware EngineerÂ to join the Engineering team. The ideal candidate will have experience working on firmware projects forÂ consumer products specifically related to HID-type devices like mice, keyboards, and headsets.RESPONSIBILITIES:
Writing, improving, and designing product firmware for gaming peripherals.
Candidate should have a solid understanding of developing firmware around high performance products. It is not enough to simply know how to write firmware for mice and keyboards: candidate should also know how firmware optimization relates to the high performing standards for gaming products.
Low latency, sensor performance, interference management are a few examples of concepts that should be understood.
Working with the Engineering team to write protocols that will integrate and interface with our gaming software suite.
Understanding and troubleshooting existing firmware source to help optimize and resolve ongoing bugs.
Ability to build new and innovating features for existing products.
REQUIREMENTS:
Full professional proficiency in EnglishÂ 

Ability to overlap with CST business hoursÂ (core hours 15:00 - 18:00)


3-4 years of experienceÂ in firmware development and embedded IC development
Knowledge of ICs must includeÂ Wireless Nordic Chipsets, STM32, and ICs with similar architecture

StrongÂ C/C++ programming skills

Experience inÂ backend developmentÂ for desktop software is preferred
A general understanding of the functionality ofÂ gaming productsÂ and how software/firmware relates to/improves/changes their performance
WE OFFER:Â 
Challenging international projects.Â 
Stable employment in a long-term partnership.
Transparently built relations based on trust and fair play.
Co-financed benefits: Medicover card, Multisport card.
